comments.commentTitle: I saw it in Grapevine Texas yesterday
comments.commentBody:
Great movie, but what really shocked me is that the theater was packed, the audience got the jokes and it was a matinée!

And I don't know what manhole Manohla crawled out from under but reading her review it seems she would rather have seen a tawdry version on The King and Mrs. Simpson a la Sex in the city.

Interesting. The book certainly deserves the acclaim and popularity it's getting now! However it came about back in the day, so glad more people are discovering this literary gem and the real Fort Smith history and U.S. Marshals heroes that inspired True Grit: http://www.awardsdaily.com/2010/11/31797/

What's amazing is that so many people are now buying tickets becuase they want to be in the audience when the "next" accident happens.

Only in New York...

Two good ones from the Midwest: Based on the true story of the Rouse Simmons, a Great Lakes schooner whose captain risks life and limb to transport fir trees from Michigan's Upper Peninsula to Chicago's German immigrants during the late 19th century. "The Christmas Schooner," http://en.wikipedia.org....

And First Stage Children's Theatre in Milwaukee just premiered "My Son Pinocchio," a rewrite of Steven Schwartz's "Geppetto and Son." Disney is involved, so I bet you'll see it in New York if you're lucky!

Remember,
This lame brain tax ruling isn't much of surprise since government and any art that is somewhat relevant never have mixed well.
I found the weight comment snarky, mean-spirited, unhelpful and irrelevant. I expect more from the Times.
Less war, more Pee-Wee. How's *that* for a New Year's resolution?

comments.userLocation: far, far from New York, thank God
comments.commentBody:
If it's this glitchy and dangerous now, just imagine what it'll be like a couple hundred performances into the run - people are tired, people are getting lazy, people are getting sloppy with rigging and technique ........... Bam. Dead show.

The whole concept sounds like blowing chaff into the face of the audience, instead of producing a well-written, well-acted play.
They're trying to pull a Springtime For Hitler. There's no other rational explanation.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
As many have pointed out, the Constitutional right to free speech isn't infringed in this case b/c there is no state action. The police weren't actively involved in restricting speech... they were enforcing the property rights of the museum. The art gallery is certainly within its right to expel any patron for whatever reason.

That said, it is a very fine line being tread by the gallery, for one I would hope that this gallery isn't benefitting in any way from government funding, or else as a taxpayer I'd be at my representative's throat since this can legitimately be construed as government tacitly endorsing discriminatory behavior.

I won't touch the large Israeli/Palestinian issue because it's a fool's pursuit. There are legitimate arguments on both sides of the debate but few are objective enough to approach the discussion with a rational mindset. As for the ejection itself... if the accounts above are to be accepted as accurate, then there was nothing "offensive" or "in your face" (as some have characterized it) about their actions. Regardless as to which side of the debate you find yourself aligned, we should all be unsettled by such random discriminatory behavior as demonstrated by the Gagosian staff.

The whole planet condemned Pastor Jones when he was going to burn the Koran.  It would nice to see something similar with this, especially in the Islamic world.  I have noticed they do not condemn antisemitism (or homophobia) and tend to see them as noble, in fact.  If we are all going to condemn Islamaphobia I want to see the Islamic leaders, religious and political, condemning this.  After all, the Isreali government issued a condemnation of Jones.  I

To Happy and proud #58 'I hope he is defrocked and tossed out of the church. Given the response of most Christian churches to antisemitism, though, I'm not holding my breath.'

We were figuring he could follow ol' Ovadia out the door. Of course, I wasn't exactly holding my breath for that one in the first place.

To M. Imberti,

I have indeed been to Israel. Spent long periods of time there in fact. That has nothing to do with being able to state there is no genocide, however. Genocide is defined as "the deliberate and systematic extermination of a national, racial, political, or cultural group." http://dictionary.reference.com... With all those who gripe about there superior military capabilities and disregard for international law, if they really wanted to "exterminate" the Palestinians, why has it not happened yet?

The Eagles lost tonight, which means Da Bears are at least a second seed in the Playoffs, so I’m in a jolly good mood and want to sing Waltzing Matilda with a slight variation to honor today’s puzzle:

Once a jolly swagman sat beside the billabong,
Under the shade of a coolibah tree,
And he sang as he sat and waited by the billabong
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me

Waltzing MY TILDE, waltzing MY TILDE
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me
And he sang as he sat and waited by the billabong
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me.

Down came a jumbuck to drink beside the billabong
Up jumped the swagman and seized him with glee
And he sang as he tucked jumbuck in his tuckerbag
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me

Waltzing MY TILDE, waltzing MY TILDE
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me
And he sang as he sat and waited by the billabong
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me.

Down came the stockman, riding on his thoroughbred,
Down came the troopers, one, two, three.
"Where's the jolly jumbuck you've got in your tuckerbag?
Who'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me?

Waltzing MY TILDE, waltzing MY TILDE
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me
And he sang as he sat and waited by the billabong
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me.

Up jumped the swagman and plunged into the billabong,
"You'll never catch me alive," cried he
And his ghost may be heard as you ride beside the billabong,
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me.

Waltzing MY TILDE, waltzing MY TILDE
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me
And he sang as he sat and waited by the billabong
You'll come a waltzing MY TILDE with me.
Sujean@18:  Had the "rating" problem too -- seems browser dependent:  I get it with Safari but not Firefox.  (Mac G4,OS 10.3)

Dr. Cohen said something revealing in response to Andy's third question:

"I have tried to stay focused on seasonal forecasting and not get distracted by global warming"

In other words, for those in search of an accurate seasonal forecast in a given region, global warming is a distraction.

Because global warming theory is not predictive of seasonal and regional climatic events.

Yet it is seasonal and regional predictions that are most critical for preparedness against hurricanes, blizzards, floods, crop failures and the other climatic disasters for which humankind must prepare.

Let's face it, a "projection" of some global climatic condition one hundred years hence is worthless.

An accurate regional prediction of climatic conditions three or six months hence would be worth billions and could save thousands of lives.

It is certainly plausible that the main inputs to Dr. Cohen's prognostications (apparently Siberian snow cover, sea surface temperatures and the state of the AO, NAO and ENSO) would have some predictive value. One can argue about whether Siberian snow cover is a cause or an effect, but the broad outlines of the method are similar to what other prognosticators with middling-to-good records, such as Joe Bastardi and Joe D'Aleo, take into account.

As long as they don't try to stir CO2 trends into the stew, it might even work.

Those organizations who insist on trying to "project" seasonal conditions based on greenhouse gas trends are going to end up looking like the UK Met Office.

Consistently and everlastingly, embarrassingly, humiliatingly WRONG.

If the Siberian snow is there (and Siberia won't go away any time soon) to alleviate any warming effects by reflecting back the solar heat, then

what in these peoples' minds is the problem?

That is, what is the problem for humanity?

The problem for them is that they made a fuss

about the minute effects of the extra 1/100 of 1% of the atmosphere (=100 ppm) in CO2 added by humans

being AMPLIFIED by all natural climate mechanisms, thus generating an

ACCELERATED GLOBAL WARMING

which is nowhere to be seen by more than a decade now.

The fact that the climate system is STABLE ENOUGH by mechanisms such as the SIberian snow was contradicted by the whole gang.

So only now they are forced to admit that the climate system system is stable? What an amazing hindsight...

Not very impressive...
It appears that China is finally buying into Capitalism.

This is hardly a surprise. Ever since the bottom line became the sole arbiter of industrial behavior, the National Security and its strategic needs have gone the way of the dodo.

Hail to the Billionaires!

Just wait until China calls in the Bush-Cheney-Rumsfeld-Republican military/industrial complex IOUs for Iraq and Afghanistan wars. We'll have to sell the White House, Capitol and Pentagon for starters. . . .

The latest Case-Schiller index(which represents the resale value of the same house) seems to imply that house prices may decline to another new low-about 8-15% below current levels. ( I reference here the articles in NYT and CSM.) This prediction implies that over the next year more houses will be under water and to buy a house now implies that the owner is willing to take a punishing loss to sell that house due to job loss or other misfortunes.  In other words, the non-liquid aspect of a house acts to drive down the desirability in owning real estate.  The other fact that prices are on averge back to 2003 levels and after further correction in the market, it will be at 2002 levels in 2011.  This represents an even more significant loss of value once a 23% correction due to inflation is applied. Thus, I do not see that these facts generate such an rosy picture for real estate and for the economy as a whole.

The country is bankrupt.  The cities and states should be allowed to declare banruptcy.  Public service unions should be disbanded and current benefits obligations should be re-organized.  Many former politicians, nationwide,  should be indicted, including the use of RICO laws.  Then, and only then, should we talk about the possibility of tax increases.

With the tax compromise, the federal government will run unsustainable deficits for at least two more years. Several states are bankrupt by any reasonable standard. The economic dominos continue to fall in Europe, as country after country is forced to face economic reality.

Meantime, the private economy shows signs of life. Let's hope our government stops trying to run the economy. It is obvious our politicians can't balance a checkbook.

The economy is not coming back until spending picks up again. Since credit is no longer available for spending, it has to come from discretionary income. Discretionary income is not coming back unless debt is reduced or incomes rise.

Not likely to happen? Well then there is only one other way to increase spending. Increase taxes on the very rich who got us into this mess to begin with and spend the money raised from the higher taxes.

Of course that will never happen because our government works for the very rich. What they will do instead is nothing to eliminate debt or mandate higher wages for workers, lower taxes for the very rich and cut spending.

This is truly the Great Recession.

"It was the year that the economy started to recover and then slid back into a slump"

That's called a double dip recession.
